reviewText:
This game has some really good parts but could use some more polish. The paucity of classes reduces the fun factor significantly. Also, the alchemist archers are fairly OP. I found the alchemists tended to run out of ammo too fast and the close up guys had too much trouble with exploding enemies to be very good most of the time, though their stun is nice once in awhile.

Combat gets repetetive pretty quick. There aren't really enough enemy types to keep it fresh. Simply adding more HP midgame does not make it more fun.

The tuitorial leaves lots of stuff out, like items and like how to prevent land from falling away into the acid."

I never feel like I get enough time with my heroes.

I really like the ideas but the execution leaves a lot to be desired.

reviewText:
The haters are amateurs and misunderstand what this game is about; this is a game about farming dozens of Pokemon and then lamenting when those Pokemon die of old age before you could force them to breed with each other. All the combat / etc. exists only to setup that moment when you realize you're promoting weird inbreeding and you realize you are DEPRAVED.

The tactical layer is purposely minimalistic, it's just enough of a battle system to support the family mechanics and timeline metaphor. Hello this attitude is REFRESHING. Like, dudes, not every game should need a wiki to understand it? Loading your game with junk is DESPERATE (e.g. Shadowrun is DESPERATE) and I'm glad this game had the confidence not to do that.

PROS:
- Doesn't care about fantasy garbage lore, it's silly in the right places and at the right times
- Battles take like 15 minutes instead of an hour, yeah sorry XCOM I don't have all day
- You get to treat humans like the cattle we are

NOT-SO-PROS:
- With no real concept of cover, archers are really overpowered, and it doesn't help when the game lets you upgrade them into INVISIBLE DEATH ARCHERS; this is a problem they couldn't have fixed without some serious overhauls to their line of sight systems... the alternative is to make archers really inaccurate, but arbitrary % failure mechanics are never fun, so I guess they decided to just let archers be the best, and I think I agree with that
- The campaign is too long, 300 years is a cool number but it's really too long, it probably should've been more like 200 years

Tremendous.  Sucked me in and wouldn't let me go... I saw bulwarks and boomstrikers in my sleep...

Scratches same itch as XCom, but adds in an element of managing your available characters ala Crusader Kings II.  Since each character can potentially fit into multiple (often conflicting and sometimes permanent) roles based on their attributes, there is always delicious decision angst.

I do wish there was more review" at the end of the game; I would have loved to analyze the timeline and my choices and traced where I ended up with all women and no men
recommended: etc.  A wrap up "family tree" would be ideal at the end of the game (though I admit it would be rather large).\n\nBut overall strongly recommend if either XCOM or Crusader Kings catches your fancy

reviewText:
I had low expectations based on previous reviews. But I disagree with them: this game is great.

The concept is very interesting. The key is not to get too attached to your heroes. They are tools, you are an immortal planner. You can't get bogged down when they die.

And while the heroes aren't the most unique characters, there are fun stories the game generates. I still remember when two heroes I threw into a mission alone together (I was stupid) somehow managed to kill almost all of the enemies. I had a breather when I realized how close they were to surviving. But there were still enemies left, and they were basically dead. So these two heroes - the last of their bloodline - walked to their inevitable doom.

Definitely not all happiness and roses, but the concept is unusual, the enemy types are mechanically interesting and fun, and the game isn't too long (~8 hours for game 1).

reviewText: The schtick of the game is that you manage a fantasy realm for 300 years in a prolonged seige from an otherworldly badguy.  You have a few bloodlines of heroes, and the top-level gameplay sees you assigning them to a few different roles.  They can be part of your vanguard (strike team used in tactical levels), you put them in baby farms keeps to produce more heroes (cause the game goes for something like ten generations), they can take on the white to become a sage (speeding your research times), and your most awesome heroes can become standards in the training crucibles (boosting all heroes kingdom-wide).\n\nMeanwhile, the badguy threat the Cadence" attacks your lands (in which you build keeps
recommended: and sagewright guilds).  You send in your vanguard and play a blessedly short tactical exercise to take them down.  There are always more attacks than you can address

so you can manage things until the endgame… assuming you can hold everything together until then.

There is a whole lot of fun fiddling and arranging what traits you want your baby farms keeps to produce.  Or who you're willing to put into the sages instead.  Or who's going to fight for you

reviewText:
So I understand why some of you didn't like this game, but reading the reviews that seems to be mostly because it was a different type of game than you thought it was. To you I can only say - I'm sorry for you, do your research better next time and be glad it wasn't an expensive game.

The breeding is somewhat repetitive, but hardly time-consuming. The point of the game is to enjoy some great fun of Tactical RPG focusing just on the battles without so much of a story, which makes the game really replayable (haven't yet, but do believe so). I really like the simplified movement/action points system, that's one thing that was a bit too tricky in Deadly Games back in the day, but this is really simplified. Think of it as a big chess game with a few variations in pieces. You do a bit of research for gear to make sure they are viable as the game progresses as well as making sure they are replaced and you have a decent variety, but aside from that it's pretty straightforward.

If you thought this was a different type of game, sorry for you. But if you like me went into this knowing EXACTLY what type of game it was, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
I played this off and on through beta, but now that it is at full release with balance, I am really enjoying it! They have done a great job with a tactical turn based game. The different classes now have great feel and I use them all. It used to be that only the long range characters were worth using, but now I love my melee caberjack's! They have done a good job with the bloodlines and aging features, and it is everything I actually was looking for when I Kickstarted it. It feels polished and pretty well balanced. Well done Doublefine.

Pros: Interesting classes and hybrid classes. Clean visuals and fairly easy UI system. Good bloodlines system, and good approach with upgrades in general.

Cons: Locations not super diverse, I wish we could choose different colors for keeps etc.

reviewText:
Like XCOM, this is a game about fog-of-war-focused tactical combat with a greater strategy layer above it, best played in Ironman Mode. XCOM is better, but this game is still worth experiencing.

Rather than being about cover management, the tactical combat part is about trying to kill enemies before they ever get a chance to attack you, where the enemies are dumb as bricks. So, sometimes entertaining, and sometimes rather unimpressive, and on the whole a bit less great.

The strategy layer is a closer match though; it's got the same level of researchyness, with the additional hero breeding mechanic. I think the tactical combat's balance kind of wears down on the strategy layer though: there are many elements that make it easier to focus on upgrading and breeding only one class, but the tactical rewards for diversifying do not really make overcoming those elements worthwhile.

Oh, and the voices in this game are rather unimpressive. Every once in a long while during a battle, one or both of the chalice-people will say something useless from their rather small set of things they can say. My favorites being Good riddance!" when an ally dies (if an enemy was killed in the crossfire)
date: and "Ha! Following my advice paid off!" (or something like that) when nobody has said anything. There are individual Red Alert 2 units that have more lines than this game. Almost."

reviewText: 20 minutes in and I'm already giving up.  Framerate was awful... maybe 15 fps on a new Mac.  Tutorial said I could hit the [End] key to perform an action but this is a Mac and it does not have an [End] key; their QA team should have caught that.  I tried dialing back the video settings to get better fps but even at the lowest settings the framerate was still lame.  So I clicked [Reset] to restore the defaults but when I clicked [Apply] nothing happened; I had to restart the game again to apply the settings.  They seem to have implemented their own proprietary keyboard driver which basically ignores my OS settings where I just tap the touchpad to perform a click... with this game I actually have to depress the trackpad hard to do a basic left click.  Maybe this game is good but after so many annoying and preventable issues so early on, I'm cutting my losses and moving on.

reviewText:
(Full disclosure: I backed this game on Kickstarter but didn't play it until the release.)

After my wife complained about the game being unplayably difficult, even on the easiest difficulty, I decided it was time to give Massive Chalice a try.

I played about half way through a full game on the normal difficulty, with tutorials on and the game difficulty doesn't seem balanced to me. Some battles are really easy then you'll have one that's nearly impossible. Because battles are spaced so far apart it's also difficult to build any kind of team because two fights from now everyone on the current team is dead of old age.

I also suspect there are some underlying game mechanics that aren't being exposed for regent marriages. By the time I finished playing I had four different keeps and figure I must have intermarried between them or something because despite having 1-2 dozen heros available of both sexes, only one or two people would show up as elligible for a regent to marry. I coudn't figure out an actual reason why this is happening so the only thing I can figure is that there's some unexposed game rule about someone marrying their cousin. =)

All in all it feels like a game that could have used a bit more work. I'm fine with bad things happening in a game like XCOM, because it's usually something I did that caused it, this game is frustrating because it feels like I did everything right" yet still ended up losing in the end."

reviewText:
I had low expectations based on previous reviews. But I disagree with them: this game is great.

The concept is very interesting. The key is not to get too attached to your heroes. They are tools, you are an immortal planner. You can't get bogged down when they die.

And while the heroes aren't the most unique characters, there are fun stories the game generates. I still remember when two heroes I threw into a mission alone together (I was stupid) somehow managed to kill almost all of the enemies. I had a breather when I realized how close they were to surviving. But there were still enemies left, and they were basically dead. So these two heroes - the last of their bloodline - walked to their inevitable doom.

Definitely not all happiness and roses, but the concept is unusual, the enemy types are mechanically interesting and fun, and the game isn't too long (~8 hours for game 1).

reviewText: Massive Chalice, much like literally every Doublefine game produced since they decided they didn't need publishers or editors, is a bit confused. On one hand, it embraces the purity of XCOM2012-style (or perhaps I should say traditional board game style") actions and has the trademark Doublefine carefully crafted aesthetic running through every level of the audiovisual presentation. On the other hand
date:
it muddles everything with occasionally pointless RNG and has perhaps three too many systems going on simultaneously in the geoscape.

Did I mention it's an XCLONE? It's an XCLONE.

There's some interesting bits resulting from the nessesarily disposable nature of your soldiers as you carefully curate their family trees to produce increasingly powerful and skilled individuals in the classes you want. It's a great twist on otherwise normal "level up your units" game design. reviewText:
Do you like X-Com: Enemy Unknown?
Do you like games that are overflowing with personality?
Do you like games where you can lose spectacularly and have a blast while doing it?

In Massive Chalice, your adventurers are your kings and queens, your scholars, and they train the next generation to keep fighting.  And your adventurers will die.  Whether it is heroically in battle or just from old age, your squad of heroes will pass on their relics and traits to the next generation.

It's Rogue mixed with X-Com and it is freaking awesome.

During my first playthrough, I was so excited to build my keeps, select the best personality traits and try to groom the most ideal bloodlines.  I built a grand cathedral for study, and put my top minds to work researching the latest and greatest technology.

And then I found that I had nobody left to go out and battle!  And then my perfect matches had marital problems!  I lost a baby and the mother during childbirth!  Everything had been going so well!  My kingdom was thriving and then RUIN!  I had rulers on thrones with no spouse to get the next generation going.  I had an army of 67 year old grenadiers who tripped and broke their hips before they even got to the enemy.  GET BACK UP AND GET IN THERE YOU GERIATRIC ADVENTURERS!!!!

They died spectacularly and my kingdom was overrun.

But holy crap was it fun.  I've never lost so overwhelmingly and yet had so much fun doing so.  The two voices that make up the Massive Chalice are hilarious and their personality is as overflowing as the water in the chalice.

This game is fantastic.  The graphics suit the gameplay and the flavour of the game spectacularly and enhance the experience.

Buy this game.
Play this game.
Lose to this game several times before you figure out how to make babies (it shouldn't be that hard, right?).

Then, once you're done losing a few times, go out there and defeat the corruption in the most spectacularly hilarious ways.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Massive Chalice (beta) is an interesting new spin on turn-based strategies. There are several levels of strategy you need to think about when playing.

You only control a small squad of 5 heroes when in combat, which means you need to use terrain and other tactics in order to survive. The death of a single hero in combat affects other areas of the game.

Everything surrounds a single goal: protect the massive talking (multi-personality I might add) chalice at the center of the map. The chalice is surrounded by regions which in turn are surrounded, from all directions, by the enemy which creeps ever closer. The big talky chalice promises it has a way to defeat the enemy but says It takes time. A lot of time"
date: so we have to defend it until then.\n\nPlacing keeps and guilds in each region takes time - I'm talking years. Fortunately the years move quite quickly. Unfortunately
recommended: the lives of your heroes span those years in real time
hoursPlayed:
which means they get old and they eventually die of old age (unless killed in battle).

In order to maintain a line of heroes you have the option to make them regents (or regent partners). This stops the heroes from entering the battlefield and instead focus of making the next generation of heroes. You now need to find the right combination of heroes to produce offspring with attributes that can defeat the enemy more efficiently.

Overall I found the game to be semi-light hearted

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is not a carbon copy of XCOM, it's more like inspired by XCOM, as well as much more difficult. The main thing this game has in common with XCOM is the combat mechanics and permadeath and these are not bad game mechanics so I believe it's acceptable. Every choice matters and your soldiers (named Heroes) WILL die and you will have to accept this. I love this game but not because of its combat, (which is very light strategy and needs some fine tuning to be satisfactory) but because of everything outside of combat. You rule a kingdom and control when time starts and stops. Time means everything in this game, as well as the age, experience, fertility, and traits of your heroes. Even some enemy designs revolve around these subjects, a type of enemy can cause you to lose experience, or make you older by 5 to 10 years, or even make you sterile. Your people WILL die on the battle field. Accept it. The artstyle is fantastic and the gameplay outside of combat is very intriguing and interesting. Now for the enemy types, the only thing I have a problem with is how powerful the enemies are. I don't mind a challenge but I believe some tweaks would improve their combat mechanics, such as for example, the Lapses who when hit a hero they drain experience, the amount of experience should dialed down. Also the variability of hit success can be infuriating at times, (f.e. 87% chance to land a successful hit and misses can be very  frustrating.) This game is a work in progress for sure, however despite it's flaws it is well worth the price and extremely fun, satisfying, and very challenging. 9.5/10! In case you don't think this review is helpful because I may be confusing in how I feel about this game, it's worth the money if you enjoy strategy games like XCOM. If you don't enjoy those types of games then you won't enjoy this one. Simple as that. For thirty bucks though this is worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game takes two of my favorite games Crusader Kings II and XCOM and mashes them together in a way that fixes some of the glaring flaws in XCOMs design.

This game takes place over Hundreds of years and you are managing a nation and stable of heroes across multiple generations. Through out the game you will build keeps to further bloodlines, crucibles for training and Sagewrights guild for research.

You will also engage in some genetic engineering through selective pairing to get the best possible heroes.
The heroes you pair do a few things. 1. They have a chance to pass along some of their traits (positive and negative) to their kids. 2. They pass along some of their XP. This alone fixes the massive flaw in XCOM, by the midgame of XCOM any new recruit you get is useless to you. Now your new recruits are able to scale in power as the game progresses.

The other big flaw involves losing" a battle. While there is no "ironman" mode that I can see

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, this is in early access, and I backed the Kickstarter at the time so take that for what it's worth.

Massive Chalice is a turn-based tactical game in the same vein as, but on a smaller scale than, X-Com.  Where it differs is in the meta-game; rather than building a base and managing resources, you're managing the family trees of your squad.  You do still research equipment and choose buildings for the different regions in the kingdom, but it's a more limited set of choices than you may be used to.  The overall aim of the game is to survive as a kingdom under threat, until the titular Massive Chalice is able to purge the threat from your lands forever.

The heroes that make up your squad (up to 5 at a time) are born, they age, gain experience and abilities, and die.  They will die a lot, and saving and reloading when a mission goes poorly won't save them.  The timeline that you are trying to survive through means that even if everything goes according to plan, your heroes will still eventually succumb to old age.  The trick is to ensure you have enough new heroes being born (with beneficial heriditary traits) to replace them.

On a functional level, the game looks and sounds beautiful.  The art design is outstanding, and I wouldn't be surprised to see it win some awards at the end of the year.  It is still in Beta, but I've not experienced any game-breaking bugs.

I've followed the development of the game throughout the process, from concept art to playing it on Steam, thanks to DoubleFine's excellent TeamStreams.  I understand why certain decisions have been made, and while there are some tweaks I'd like to see to the balancing, overall the game is challenging, fun, pretty, and a triumph for open game development that I hope more developers learn from in the future.  :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

THIS IS A BETA REVIEW.

I've played about 2 hours of the game (30 years of the 300 year timeline). So far, I like the game, and I see potential for continued improvement before the final release.

The game does play like a fantasy X-COM in a lot of ways, but I was also reminded of the random good and bad traits from Rogue Legacy. These affect your strategic choices because many can be transmitted genetically (so be careful who you choose to found bloodlines) or socially (so be careful who you appoint as trainers). I also feel losing a valuable soldier hurts less in Massive Chalice than in X-COM, because all your soldiers are going to age and die anyway. It's a neat twist.

WHAT I LIKE:
- the graphics are charming; I like the style
- the choices on the strategic planning map are challenging and I feel there are probably multiple good (no best") choices

WHAT I'D LIKE TO SEE CHANGED:
- unit variety I'd like more than three classes
date: and some way to "blend" abilities of different classes (e.g.
recommended: one parent's an alchemist and the other's a hunter
hoursPlayed: so the kids they raise are a little bit of each)\n- silly catchphrases make me roll my eyes a bit; maybe the "serious mode vs. silly mode" setting (I forget what it's actually called) isn't implemented yet?\n- eventually

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having completed my first game, I would liken Massive Chalice as a XCOM light in a fantasy setting, with a twist; bloodlines. Light because it doesn't have the depth and content of XCOM. There is little explanation on what Cadence really is, and there are only 2 types of missions; defend the keep and defend the territory, aside from the final mission. That said, the game is also about half the price of XCOM.

The concept of bloodlines is interesting but unfortunately, the drawback is that your heroes die so fast from aging, you will not develop any attachment to them, unlike XCOM. You will have to plan carefully on what to do with your heroes, making sure that you have a sufficient fighting force and at the same time, enough set aside to research and continue the next generation.

In my opinion, while the game is fun, it needs more polish, balancing and CONTENT. I wouldn't mind paying more if the game has more content. As it stands, I would rate it a 7/10.
voteText: 24 of 50 people (48%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've lost 40 hours to this game in the early stages of beta, and I'm still ready for more. The game is great as it is, but will only become more balanced, polished and rewarding in the run up to the spring 2015 release.

I kickstarted this game, and the team have been really responsive, streaming their development progress every couple of weeks the whole time, and it's been fun to be a part of, so if the idea of helping fine tune a game's mechanics sounds cool to you, I'd definitely consider Early Access. So far they've been responding really well to everyone's feedback with several significant balance tweaks in the short 3 weeks since the backer beta began.

Even if you just want to play the game, there's a fine XCOM style strategy already working here with a generational twist, and if that sounds like your thing, I can totally recommend picking it up either now or once it's totally done in the spring if you'd rather play something completely done - but you can play it start to finish right now and have a great time.

Add in super distinctive art direction and a wonderful soundtrack, as well as some very Double-Finey touches to the world building and writing, and this is one of my favourite games of the year, which is quite an achievement for something that's still got a few months of development left to go!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Train your heroes, guide them in battle and then make sure that enough of them get married and have children that you can repeat the process.

This game is all about pitting the needs of the realm's future against the need to guard the realm from present danger and I loved playing through it even in its current early access state.

The turn based combat is reminiscent of XCOM or Shadowrun returns but instead of managing cover you need to manage line of sight, enemies that cannot see you cannot shoot you. Keep that in mind and remember neither side gets overwatch.

This is just an initial review for the 7.2 hours I've managed to put into the game so far (year 150) so please keep that in mind.

I feel that Massive Chalice wants to be more than just a tactics game, more than just an empire game. Where the game is now, however, it's not /quite/ there - but it more than easily has that potential. The attacks on your kingdom force you to truly build up a team of heroes that rival the forces of the Cadence, while at the same time making you choose which of those heroes will carry on a bloodline, teach trainees, and who will carry on the research. The balancing act is, by itself, a game that put me to a bit of a challenge, at first.

As I said, I feel that this game wants to do two things at once, which is fine. But in the wise, immortal words of Ron Swanson; Never half ♥♥♥ two things

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just bought this game, and i'll say god..its difficult and fun. But it lacks just that tad bit more of content, such as customization, and maybe bigger maps, squads and that managing your kingdom feel. On its own however, its still wonderful. I'll list down the pros and cons and an overall opinion.

Pros: Combat is wonderful, nearly like xcom though there's no cover mechanic but obstacles do block your line of sight.
Heroes can get married, and they can have offspring which mean more soldiers. (Dont think much of the FAMILY TREE, incest happens in this game as you 'll gradually lose heroes and lack the time to recruit more due to research),

Which part of the kingdom you fight on will actually matter in terms of tactics you can use.

Random events, which is always a +

Mechanics, are just wonderful and cornering your opponent especially the big ones are important.

RELICS though you might want a tier 2 weapon at the least

Cons: You can only do one action at a time, so you cant construct, recruit  and research at the same time, can be a pro if you like the game to be more tough.

Enemy AI can be dumb...... if there's a wall between you and them, they'll stick to the wall (in my instance it was a low wall and they just ran and stayed there, like fish in a barrel)

You can't expand your squad and you also cant escape from battle just like in x-com = can be a +

Opinion: It's a great game, i just wish for customization, kingdom management and maybe even some multiplayer. Try it you'll likely not regret buying and playing this game


Ok finally finished.... its good not great but yeah, worth its price considering how much you can play and how many ways you can play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So long story short, this is an amazing squad based tactical game with some awesome decision making/advanced planning thrown in. However if you arent convinced, here are some pros and cons

1. Awesome tactical combat once you get the hang of it
2. A good mix of humorous and serious tones
3. Gorgeous art style.
4. Challenging but rewarding leveling
5. Great difficulty, challenging but never unfair
6. Character breeding. Take two characters together, make a keep, slap them together, and boom! Warrior baby! or lowly peasant baby, all depends really.
7.Ability to research different upgrades, buildings, and character skills for different play styles
8. passing of weapons of fallen heroes
9. The story plays over 300 years so you have to plan in advanced to get good heroes that were created due to the hard work of their ancestors who you controlled in battle leading to a lineage of heroes.
10. Random events occur as time passes and you get to pick the result, each with its own consequences

All is not perfect however. There are a few drawbacks

1. Only 3 classes
2. Not too many abilities for each class
3. The tutorial is a bit convoluted. It confused me more than it should have. It plays like all other tactical games but you wouldnt know by the diagram they throw at you.
4. Not a lot to reasearch
5. A lack of options in most areas. There are a few but not nearly enough

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I backed Massive Chalice on Kickstarter and it's probably one of the best decisions I've made, in terms of money spent on games.

The game plays like long-form, fantasy X-Com. You control a squad of heroes against a force of maurauding monsters. Instead of aliens, however, you fight the Cadence. Demonic entities that can corrupt the land, steal experience from your champions, and even age those they touch by years at a time. Your champions wield bow, flask, and caber in the defence of your kingdom.

Your advantage in this war? An immortal king (the player) who can guide the battles of the nation over the course of centuries, and the Chalice, which can charge up over this time to lay waste to the Cadence on a global scale.

Over the course of 300 years, you'll research new weapons and technologies, build keeps and other fortifications, and most importantly, guide the destinies of heroic bloodlines. For while the combat is similar in concept to X-Com, you do not recruit new heroes out of thin air. They must be bred.

The strongest champions become regents, and through arranged marriage, their children are made stronger. Weak traits are weeded out, strengths are promoted over the course of generations. Will your bloodlines become strong enough to make the final push to wipe out the Cadence?

With the latest patch to the beta game, there are now Hybrid classes that greatly mix up the combat, and I have been having a blast. (although the pure Hunter, Alchemist, and Caberjack classes are still fun). Personally I like the ****/Alchemist hybrids the best.

In short, the game gives us tactical, squad-based combat on an epic scale, and somehow makes Eugenics fun.

Go play it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brilliant game, given it's just gone into beta. Dripping with character; especially driven by the two voice-actors, who are both brilliantly acted and scripted.

Wonderful to see original character classes (caberjacks, hunters, and alchemists) and not see the stereotypical fantasy tropes (fighter, mage, cleric, barbarian etc).

Interface presents very much like XCom, which is a good thing. Simple-enough to use, but all the things you want are there: line-of-sight, rotation, stealth, alternate attacks, visible chance-to-hit, etc.

Graphics are very obviously polygonal--such that you wonder if its intentionally stylistic. But maybe that's rendering that needs to happen between now and production.

My double-fine thumbs are raised!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think this game is great so far. It is XCOM with a twist, however I think that the game does need a little work

two things that come to mind

Time passes to quick, the maximum amount of missions one hero seems to get to go on is 3 (4 if you start them at 15 years old and they live to be 87). Building up one unit almost has no pay off, apart from being able to give someone in his/her bloodline a boost when they die.

Enimies get really hard really fast, I have heard this complaint from others, but it's true, I have completely wiped a few times. This challenge is part of what makes a game like Massive Chalice great, but I think it is just a bit too hard (an no difficulty option to make it a little easier on you.)

It's a great game and I'm sure that Double Fine is going to be able to make it really wonderful.

The gameplay is fun and involved, the lineage system is truly revolutionary.

Would've 9/10 + except for a few things. I know its still in beta, but getting past around year 100 is extremely difficult, to the point of impossible, and the gameplay has too much missing. (i know this sounds silly, missing is a good mechanic that can make things more lifelike), but in a strategy based game, especially at higher levels, it makes it very hard to plan attack strategies around the immensly strong enemies when you miss so often. each character has their sweet spots and you can even upgrade an item to make them more accurate, but it is still stressful. The alchemist which are supposed to be weak units that must hit from afar only start with 5 bombs, and you have to be within 2-3 spaces to get anything higher than a 60%, so they die. alot. even melee units, some units will get around a 60% when attacking at point blank. yet some get 100%. im not quite sure how this is supposted to work.

Its a fantastic game, however I don't believe a strategy game's difficulty should be based around missing your target or not. (especially when the enemies have 4x your health and they dont miss half as much as you do, and deal more damage).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

MASSIVE CHALICE is worth buying if you're a fan of XCOM, or like the idea of long term management along with tactical combat. The management seems more complex than XCOM, but at the end of the day you're just looking at numbers. Combat isn't as complex as XCOM since there isn't cover or many advanced tactics, but it is still fun. The game will last you about 15-20 hours, and it does have some good replayability since you can take a different research route. The only things left to really add to the game are difficulty levels and IRON mode, which will probably just prevent you from loading your game whenever.

A video shows most of what the game is about:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ueuGozXLxS0

http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6856568-Should-You-Play-This-Game/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In this game, you are an immortal and immobile ruler of the kingdom besieged by evil poisonous monsters. The talking Chalice is going to purge the monsters in 300 years, so you have to survive that period with the help of the warriors you recruit, manage and guide in turn-based X-COM-like battles. There is a twist - be it a kingdom management projects or hero level-ups, it takes long time. LONG time. Years, decades, literally. So the value of each investment and decision is becoming critically high.
Your heroes are aging and dying of old age, as well as in battle, so you have to account for it by retiring them from active roster to form a family and produce offspring - your new cannon fodder. You can also retire them to research and training instituions- with age heroes get increased wisdom" property

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is being worked on intensely and things are changing all the time, so much of this is subject to change.

Short version: It's fun. It's hard. It's relatively bug-free.

MC seeks to address a lot of the issues with squad-based tactics games like X-COM, primarily by making character death less of an issue. The fact that even your best warriors will eventually die of old age means that losing a few in battle doesn't NECCESARILY require a restart of the entire mission. Heck, if they die in battle they might turn into a magical weapon for your other warriors to use.

That being said, there are issues, though most of them just come with the territory in this type of game. There are a lot of things to research and build, and all of them take a long time. If things start going badly for you, don't expect them to stop. Sure, you have a crucible to train your new recruits, but without someone to staff it, it does no good. If you find yourself low in units and your birthrate isn't good, you can go scour for new recruits, but it takes years.

reviewText:
What I can say about Massive Chalice is odd. It's a game that is at the same time very neat, and very clunky.

For example the combat (one of the things you'll be doing the most) is laid out in a neat way, the UI is good. You get a lot of information (although not enough like the game not telling you if you'll be in the range for a melee attack) without it cluttering the interface.
That however doesn't make the actual combat any better. While at first it might be enjoyable to experiment with various classes you quickly discover strategies that work best for your current line-up and stick to them.

For example if you play with a lot of hunters you'll be doing a lot of sneaking and alpha striking the enemy to blow him up before he can react, as kaberjacks you'll notice that enemies take damage by getting knocked back into walls AND into units. So you'll abuse that fact for more damage+stun potential, alchemists are really only good against the weakest enemies in the game. so after the start they only really serve to make kaberjack and hunter hybrids. But that creates a problem for the other game mechanics.

The breeding. It is supposed to be a big part of the game but really it turns into a chore. The mechanics are never explained properly so you have to do a lot of guesswork to understand how to do it properly. It is important to remember that your kids will not only get the traits of the parents, but also possibly random ones or traits from the OTHER members of the family tree, OR perks that you didn't even know the family has. This is extremely frustrating in the early game and if not managed properly becomes a problem in the mid and even late game.

Imagine this scenario. You decide that you'll base your early game on kaberjacks (and you have to decide who to base it on early because you only get one castle at start). Cool. You built your castle, you find a good young couple with a high fertility rating and good kaberjack stats and mush them together. Recipe for success right? No.

Now it took your super fertile mating pair anywhere between 0 and 40 years to pop their first baby. They might NEVER get one even though the release day patch supposedly altered the numbers. But hey, there is a kid! Oops he's asthmatic and anaemic. So he can't run and he has reduced hp. WHy is that?! Oh because both family trees had those perks hidden in their genes and you had absolutely NO way of knowing that. Enjoy.

Now imagine you're doing this for 300 in-game years while having to constantly bring in new blood (and new bad traits) because upkeeping a family that is provided for is apparently a really hard task.

So yeah, neat idea, pretty dull and clunky execution. Same you could say for most of the game.

Honestly if this is how Double Fine keep doing things I think I'll just stop buying things from them altogether.
voteText: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game, this game is so good. At this point I have almost gotten to 300 years on my third try playing it and I'm having a blast with the subclasses and items you can get. The combat is very simple and looks odd, but you get used to it over time and the it's dullness will seem normal by the end. The best thing is giving a two year-old child or a seven year-old a powerful relic, or listening to the chalice comment on your decisions. I know it feels and plays like a copy of Xcom, nut you really have to look past those kinds of flaws and not really compare a game to others that clearly outclass it. That doesn't seem fair to me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review of the .96b beta

Shorter Review: A mixture of kingdom management, tactical battles, RPG, and hero breeding that  produces a satisfying game requiring thought and planning  Still being polished, but looking promising, and worth it if this is your area of interest.

To review Massive Chalice, you need to start with the story.

You're an Immortal regent, bound to a mysterious chalice holding the souls of past heroes.  That chalice is the only hope of your nation to cleanse it of the foul creatures that threaten it, the mysterious Cadence.  You'll rally heroes to fight, decide how to run the kingdom, and figure out how to survive.  Good thing you're immortal, because your heroes are not, and you'll need to plan how to use them, marry them, retire them, and pass on their legacies.  You've got a 300 year war ahead of you until the Chalice is powerful enough to end it, and everyone who started the battle with you will be dust when it's over . . .

Massive Challice is a game that combines several play mechanics in a way that's easy to pick up - hard to master.  That's not an emplty statement - it's the truth, because the simple parts interact in many ways.
* A straightforward, effective, but deep tactical battle game where heroes fight monsters.
* An RPG system where you manage characters, equipment, and skills.
* A straightforward, but detailed hero-breeding system where you establish lineages of heroes - who inherit traits, legacies, relics, and more.
* A (rather light) Kingdom management game that consists of making choices of battles, what to construct, and how to react to random events.

In Massive Challice, you alternate battles with the Cadence and managing your kingdom and heroes over the course of 300 years.  One moment you're deciding who to attack, the next deciding what to build next, then responding to a random event, and finally trying to figure out if you should intermarry two heroic linages - then another battle may arise.  You're constantly scaling your strategy and tactics as you play, and how the different levels of the game mesh is a big part of the challenge and satisfaction - there's something about watching a new, well-trained hero of a class you unlocked due to an unusual marriage wield a weapon of his bloodline on the first go to cause massive damage.

This means that this is a game of planning and management - even when you're whomping on the Cadence.  Because time is tight, resources are limited, and enemies are tough you are always constrained, always evaluating, always scheming - and often regretting.  Death is permanent, decisions aren't reversable (well unless you're using a save game and not playing in Iron Mode), and time and resources lost aren't easily reclaimed.  You will start over, you will reload saves - and if this is your kind of game, you will go back again and again.

The combat, I think, deserves special note as it's well balanced.  There's 3 main classes and descendents via crossbreeding can unlock 6 more classes.  Stealth, special abilities, the right equipment, planning, and above all patience are requires for victory.  Pulling off massive kills and victories is quite satisfying and good planning is rewarded.  This is a precise, well done part of the game that was both deep yet completely accessible and intuitive.

Regarding Hero breeding" part of the game

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFantastic game in most aspects. The musical direction is superb, the combat has its own unique yet familiar feel, and the game will have you do some selective breeding. The things I feel that could use some work are the usefulness of classes, such as the caberjack, which is a melee brute-like class that I let die out everytime I had one, not on purpose, but because I gave Hunters and Alchemists priority. The hybrid classes are what filled my ranks however, each one is unique and they mix classes from both of the parent's classes. The decision you make is what traits you want to have your future soldeirs to carry. I binged this game, mainly because that's how I intake these things. The game is fantastic and I will be doing another run through because the game was a bit too easy, and it was kind, I got hawkeyed and longetivity traites for most of my beginnner soldiers. So seeing them die at the age of 70 was sad but I felt good knowing that others can die at 40~. If anything the game's ending (no spoilers) could use a bit more of an expansion or some work, I just think it needs that legacy" feel as the whole game is literally built around legacies

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's early access so beware if you're not willing to put up with that.
Right now it's kind of a mixed stew for me. I like the concept and much of what's implemented. Haven't had time to play alot yet but I can list some +/- at least.

+
The gfx style is kind of an aquired taste but it reminds me of games such as the Interstate '76 series. It's quite nice in it's simplicity.

The Bloodline Genetics system adds some depth to the game.

The voiceover for the chalice ... ghosts?

Fighting. It's not very complex but satisfying, mostly.

Easy to get started but from what I can tell mastering it will take some practice.

-
Randomness. Yes there's always gonna be some degree of randomness but I feel it's a bit harsh sometimes. Like spawning in the middle of a big pack of cadence, assigning two healthy middle age heros to a castle and having one of them dying in a year with no children. Etc. If bad luck like this was rare I guess it would be fine but it's happened a couple of times in my short playtime.

I think the time progresses a bit fast. Now don't get me wrong I don't want the game itself that much slower, build and research times don't need to be longer. But I'd like to spend a little more time with my heros. To get to know them better during combat etc. Mabe more frequent encounters would work as well.

About half of the cadence I've faced so far explode making Caberjacks alot less useful than hunters and alchemists. This might work itself out when I get further and can start upgrading armor, get them to higher levels etc. But early game I don't really see the point to them. The cadence that don't explode can be killed just as easy by the two ranged classes. And while caberjacks get charge at level 1 and it has a knockback it has cooldown and if it doesn't finish the cadence off it can just walk up and explode next to the caberjack when your turn ends. Would be good if even at low levels with no upgrades to gear caberjacks had more health or better damage mitigation so they had better survivabilty,

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Full disclosure: I am a Kickstarter backer and have been following the production very closely.

This game delivers exactly what was said: a generations-long war on an epic timeline. Mechanically excellent combat, and a great aesthetic.

Not much story to speak of, but that's not really a bad thing.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFantastic game in most aspects. The musical direction is superb, the combat has its own unique yet familiar feel, and the game will have you do some selective breeding. The things I feel that could use some work are the usefulness of classes, such as the caberjack, which is a melee brute-like class that I let die out everytime I had one, not on purpose, but because I gave Hunters and Alchemists priority. The hybrid classes are what filled my ranks however, each one is unique and they mix classes from both of the parent's classes. The decision you make is what traits you want to have your future soldeirs to carry. I binged this game, mainly because that's how I intake these things. The game is fantastic and I will be doing another run through because the game was a bit too easy, and it was kind, I got hawkeyed and longetivity traites for most of my beginnner soldiers. So seeing them die at the age of 70 was sad but I felt good knowing that others can die at 40~. If anything the game's ending (no spoilers) could use a bit more of an expansion or some work, I just think it needs that legacy" feel as the whole game is literally built around legacies

reviewText: I've heard that the dev. team from the original XCOM game was put into this new title. As a turn-based strategy genre fan, I was very excited and looking up for this game as some kind of a new XCOM. However, it is not as what I hoped for. I couldn't feel any emotion or any regret for the characters upon their deaths. They would have died for old age anyway with or without diving into a combat which would make their basic characteristics doesn't matter at all. The game could have been better if there are more developments are put in the game. I couldn't see much the same from the original XCOM. I got this on sale so I won't be complaining much, but it is still good if it is a bit cheaper. I wish for a neutral button between yay and nay, or a poker face as my expression.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First Review ever on steam!

One it's in early access so there is more to come but form what I've played it's got alot of potential to become a very great game.

ok my review!
If you liked X-Com: Enemy unknown, Grand Strategy games, state breading (pokemon style) and a simple but hard game play. Try this game!

The combat comes down to a very few things, range attacks, AoE, melee and knock back. The enemies have there own strengths and weaknesses, but though the use of your Heros you can over come the enemies (mosly by combos of keep you enemy away and taking them down one at a time). The story is well something intresting, you can have it narrated straight forwerd or silly.

The combat can be overwellming when you have to many enemies to fight off at once (4 or more different provoked enemies will kill someone or your whole party)

What I hope comes to the full version is
-more classes
-AI boss enemies (maybe evolving like you heros though some breading)
-AI that know how to run away to fight again with there fellow enemies
-AI that try to flank or trick you into a fight
-more weapons
-making your own custom Families/House (banner and Names)

All in all really good game, you may find your self saying  oh just a few more years

Early Access Review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Works as advertised. For an early access / beta the game it performs well with little to no bugs (there were 1 maybe 2 but they were so minor I can't remember them).

The aethetics of the graphic design is a pleasure to look at and the UI is quite clean and easy to understand. The rolling time line is punctuated with births, deaths, attacks and the occaisonal random event. In essecence theses are a test of your strategy. Do you have enough characters? are they upto the task ? Do you have enough breaders and other trainees to full the other roles?

There have been one or two comments previously saying this is no XCOM. This is true but the game is not trying be that. With the exception of the turnbased tactical combat, the game is not about micro managment or drowning in a sea of stats but rather seeing how a few crucial decisions playout over the long term.

All in all an enjoyable game thus far.

reviewText:
The important thing to note is that it is a strategy RPG. This means moving each individual piece across a map to remove Fog of War until you see the enemy and then, finally dealing with them. In addition, some of the enemies blow up when you kill them and some of your characters only do melee damage. . .  so you have to deal with only using them in melee range, but also not killing the enemies that blow-up with them. It doesn't have the speed, long sight lines, and variety of ranged attacks that made XCOM an enjoyable strategy RPG either.

I'm in love with the concept of Bloodlines and family traits for a generation-spanning RPG, but the appeal of that is killed by the fact that the game is a strategy RPG. Additionally, I imagined handsome heroes growing up from adolescents who are learning their craft to young adults honing it, to mature adults achieving their legacy, to elders securing and nurturing it, but the art is so stylized that the humans look monstrously mishapen. . .  I'm not wondering what my hero's kids will look like because it will just be some flavor of ugly.

Unfortunately, Massive Chalice's ideas had some great traits, but they were bread with some ideas with bad traits, the resulting offspring has suffered.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't recommend this game in it's current state. There's a promising core strategy game, but I find a lot of the mechanics to be unfun, and the balance to be... meh.

1.) The enemies on the tactical map don't seem to move? You can trigger a lot of them all at once for no good reason. I prefer the XCOM style in which enemies patrol, and you can play a slightly more conservative/defensive game.
2.) Enemies can take away XP and de-level your heroes. No thanks, not fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is already a pretty complete game, and worth the purchase.

The combat is X-Com style, but a good portion of your troops will be melee, so cover is less of a deal. It's mostly about staying outside of the attack range of enemies, and ganging up on them one at a time. (By the end of the game you can sometimes eliminate one enemy per soldier per game though).  The soldier classes are pretty fun, especially the caberjack, which can push and stun enemies. If enemies are stacked in a line, he can even stun more than one. He synergizes well with the alchemist, who can drop some bombs on the enemies he's shoved together. The hunter is a little less impressive, but it's excellent to have one on the team due to the stealth abilities they get from the start. I understand DF is also working adding some hybrid classes.

The strategic game has a pretty steep learning curve. Your soldiers will maybe get 4 combats in over the course of their lifetimes, and so you need to build a dynasty. It's a mix of ensuring fertility (many offspring), experience (new soldier experience depends on regent at keep and standards at crucibles), and positive traits (a bit of eugenics between experienced regents and desirable mates). My first couple runs, I couldn't fill out my combat roster on the 5th or so combat.

Gripes: later on there are advanced versions of the enemies, which basically just have 2x hp and 2x damage. They don't even color swap them. Learning curve is a bit too steep at the start.

Early Access Review

The game is fairly streamlined like the XCom remake, and borrows a lot from that design. I am curious to see what features and improvements are coming, and hope they can make the game feel richer and fuller without bogging it down and complicating it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Right, this one gets a cautious recommendation, mostly because of the combat. Also, points for being one of a few Early Access games that's actually complete, but just needs more content (you know, the way it's supposed to be).

Story: the story is, you are a god-like entity brought into being by the Massive Chalice to save the lands from the encroaching Cadence, which you will do over the stretch of three hundred years. I liked the dual voices of the Massive Chalice, and there's nothing to really complain about on that front.

Gameplay: You control different houses, and attempt to keep the bloodlines going throughout the three hundred years required for the chalice to activate while fighting off occasional incursions and doing research to improve the lands/heroes. It's a very good system, and the moment the game gave me a character in the Armstrong lineage named Alex-Louis"
date: the idea of passing down his Alchemist technique through the Armstrong line for generations never stopped being funny.\n\nThe rub (and indeed
recommended: the caution part of this tale) is in the combat. This game most clearly takes influence from XCOM: Enemy Unknown and (to a lesser extent) Fire Emblem: Awakening. Problem is

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI adore this game. It could be seen as a fantasy X-Com, however it brings many different tweaks and features to the table. This is something I've supported since Kickstarter and I have not at all been disappointed. The developers have been amazing. I know many have become leery of Double Fine because of Spacebase DF9 but do NOT let that dissuade you from enjoying this exceptional game. Now obviously the game is not finished yet. It still needs it's final polish and is missing hybrid classes at this point. As of now there are only the 3 main classes in the game the Hunter, Alchemist, and Caberjack (my personal favorite). However, during production there was talk of an additional fourth class if the game sells well. The art style takes a little while to get used to but I enjoy it. Gameplay may seem a little unbalanced right now but as everyone knows this is still early access. What distinguishes this game from X-Com is the idea that it takes place over 300 years. Because of this you will not be able to play the entire game with one or even two squads. Your heroes will die one way or another, it's up to you to choose whether this death is in old age or if it is a glorious one on the battlefield. If your heroes are experienced enough when they die they will leave behind a wonderous relic for their family to use. The way you get more heroes is by establishing Game of Thrones style family keeps in regions, and these keeps produce more heroes from your chosen bloodlines to protect the lands. So if any of this sounds appealing to you I would definitely recommend this game. Especially because Double Fine has involved the testing community to the extreme and will gladly incorporate your input if you leave it on their forum.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What to expect from this game at the moment? Sleepless night, maybe multiple depending.

Research and other options could be more deeper and more varied, there things like putting your most experienced guy to train others that you just have to do and ensure a steady flow of new people through your keeps but after you have these running there are not too many surprises around to be seen and the game begins to feel stale.

Combat is your new standard XCOM style without action points, although it's much more varied with traits, personalities adding to the experience and also levels affecting the damage output with weapon relics that gather their own experience adds a very welcome and nice twist to the whole combat.

AI of the enemy is rather straight forward, it's out there to kill you and doesn't get scared or have personalities.

This is EARLY ACCESS review so things might change to be more involving, but core design of the game will not change so you can assume this is a feature complete game at the moment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WAIT FOR THE FINISHED GAME!!!

Now that I have that out of the way you may notice how I still recommend it. And that's because I want to emphasize that the game is still fun, just VERY VERY frustrating.The game is very fun and could be very addictive... once they fix the issue of difficulty and others. Think of the game like Xcom if it met with Game of Thrones, with the idea of making families out of heroes that will produce offsprings. On paper this is fantastic and for the most part the execution is more than decent enough when you consider the budget. The mechanics of choosing X or Y is not as punshing as XCom where the latter makes you feel like you just ruined the lives of millions  if you choose one continent over the other. Some complaints I have right now that will make me stop playing the game for now in hopes they'll be addressed:

1. Right now how far you get in the game is EXTREMELY dependent on how lucky you are with your initial role of heroes, ages, and classes. For example I just rolled a game where I had like 4 melees and 1 archer. I then made the highest ranked melee into the regent and gave her a partner to produce babies. By the time I built my second keep to get a new regent, I only had one Archer at a decent level, and once I put that one as a regent to give me high level archers I was basically F'ed because I had no other archers for battles, so now I need to fight battles with nothing but melee and alchemists. Which is extremely hard once you hit level 40.

So the issue at hand is that the regent/lineage system needs rework. Having to wait 15 years minimum for your next generation of a specific class is horrible. You don't get enough heroes.

2. Heroes don't level up unless you bring them with you to battles and use them to kill enemies. It's fine by itself if you were given higher level heroes, but you tend to be given low level heroes.

3. Bulwarks or w/e they're called are broken. So is whatever system that decides how many enemies you gotta fight at a time. I'm in year 40 and I got a map with bulkwarks in groups of 2 and I had to fight like 10 with nothing but melees and one archer. This was a pain, but then like three more appeared. If you're gonna have these guys gain a shield after an attack at least don't make it where damage goes down to 1. Or lower their base damage, because 5-7 per hit is ridiculous.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just a short review of the game as it's in Early Access December 2014. I've tried two playthroughs by now.  The first went haywire so I restarted, the second I made it to Year 300 (end game). I think there's a bit of a learning curve still :)

Anyway, I really, really like the game. It reminds me of a hybrid between XCOM (new one) and The Last Federation. The XCOM part is somewhat simpler in regard to the combat, yet it has its own flavor and you have some pretty clever things you can pull off with the different classes, equipment and skills. As to the Kingdom/Base Management it's two widely different beasts. Where XCOM had a lot of smaller research paths and many types of equipment there are fewer in Massice Chalice, so every choice counts - and smacks - like a b*tch.

If I had to pick one great feature of the Kingdom Management it's the breeding for various traits in the regents' children. It makes a heck of a difference. If you marry two regents with bad traits your resulting heroes will be so pathethic it's painful.

Right now it's not just playable but also enjoyable. I don't know for sure if there's just a lot more learning to do for me or if there are genuine imbalances in the game. I miss the feeling of late game XCON where you're very powerful and just kill scores of enemies. Actually, the second game I'm not sure I'll actually be able to complete, and I got this nagging feeling that maybe, just maybe, I shouldn't have paired that decent regent with that too young, unknown spouse.

Perhaps with the right bloodline with the right traits and personality ...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I just finished my first run-through of the game, and I can honsetly say I enjoyed it immensely. A lot of people are jittery about DF having another early access game, but the situation has been made perfectly clear: MASSIVE CHALICE is COMPLETELY FUNDED for the next six months, which is the perfect amount of time to tweak this game to perfection. You may notice a few rough edges and for some people an intimidating learning curve, but the mechanics of this game are solid and have a surprising amount of depth. Like many tactical games, you might build yourself into a corner or find yourself on the wrong end of RNG, but when this game is humming, it's an amazing experience. I can't wait for DF to put the finishing touches on this game and I hope you guys enjoy!

Other Misc Facts:
-3 base classes currently, hybrid classes planned for future update (which ups the number of options significantly)
-Get your highest level characters to be regents: XP is passed on to children of the house. The higher the XP, the higher level your trainee heroes become.
-Relics spawn occaisionally when a hero dies. Usually happens when a hero kills a lot of cadence throughout their life. Get these early and keep them in the hands of the fighting members of the family. They level up and turn wimpy heroes into super men/women.
-Be smart about movement and sight. Scout ahead with Hunters (using their sneaking ability). Sometimes your sight range is greater than theirs and often it is greater than their movement/attack range. Find the enemy first and utilize crowd control abilities to slow down the enemy (Flarrow blinds enemies for a turn, Knockback can shove enemies into other enemies and can stun each one affected, Prime Target can draw strong opponents away from weak or stranded heroes)

Have Fun guys!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Works very well if you're willing to use your imagination in a lot of aspects, and I don't mean that in a bad way. This is a game that wants you to take a second and come up with your own storyline, and if you care about the heroes in your kingdom you'll have a lot more fun than speed running, min-maxing, and generally just treating it like an old SNES game that needs to be beaten than an interactive and deep story/narrative driven epic like it is.

Edit: After playing some more, I wanted to make some remarks about the other reviews here. A lot of people complain that the game doesn't really have much in the ways of a tutorial. This creates a really good environment though. In the game, you're new to everything. You're learning what is going just like everyone else, so not knowing the exact stats of a Bulwark but instead getting a narrative description of what it does is actually really satisfying and flavorful.
Another point, I've come to really enjoy the breeding. Some people say it isn't predictable, but I can clearly tell which bloodlines are carrying what traits. Yes, some of them will show up more randomly, especially if you have regents with personalities that cause personalities to not be followed, like rebel, but that's honestly how life works. If you have 5 kids, they'll have core beliefs and fringe beliefs and both will make up who they are.
For me, a very solid 8/10. Not sure why there are so many negative reviews or why so many people are agreeing with them. I feel like it has to do with how quickly people want to burn through a game on Steam, but this is really a good Double Fine production and it shows with good narrative storytelling and character development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

X-Com meets Rogue Legacy. It's X-Com style combat with the generational traits that Rogue Legacy has. There's a pretty strong emphasis on breeding your bloodlines well to concentrate good traits and training ability as early heroes tend to be pretty mediocre (if not flat out bad). Surprisingly fun. The main thing is that it's hard to grow attached to individual characters as they get rotated out pretty quickly; however the bloodlines seem to often breed a couple of traits 'true' for many generations, giving them a bit of a personality of their own.

Combat is fairly simple, but this isn't necessarily a bad thing; I found that I didn't really want to spend hours on a tactical map at a time, since so much of the activity happens strategically. The tactical combat is just enough to be interesting without being too time-consuming, maintaining a quicker pace than e.g. Medieval.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hero breeding is cool. Everything else feels sorta bad. The game sorta splits the difference between XCOM and Fire Emble-style melee strategy (pretty much XCOM, though). It turns out that most of what drives XCOM's loop is the cover-to-cover movement.

My experience with MC so far has been to move a guy somewhere, then move other guys closer to him.

The names are cool but the catch phrases are dumb and I wish that DoubleFine hadn't Bypassed Oppressive Publishers at the cost of having heroes say cool stuff when they win.

The UI feels weird to me, but you can figure it out in a couple of minutes (hint: the weirdly stacked flags? those are hero family crests that represent their turn order.)

The story is super unfunny to me but who cares strategy game etc

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Cadence attacked in the window between almost all of my heros dying of old age and their children coming of age to be battle ready, leaving me with 2 hunters and a caberjack (all level 3) to defend a territory in immediate danger of being overrun by corruption. Fortunately, I'd just researched the stealth cloak that let the hunters hide anywhere, not just behind cover. Unfortunately this battle included a new enemy type that had triple the hp of any of my heroes.

With careful planning, a little patience, and those wonderful stealth cloaks, my heroes took out 20 cadence between them, and all three survived (and leveled twice each).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: This is my first game from this developer. I've become aware of a small scandal brewing about this developer's past games, but this review is written with ONLY THIS PARTICULAR GAME in mind. I have no idea what happened with the developer's previous games, and thus that is not the concern of this review.

In the time I've spent with this, I've really enjoyed it. It has all the features it claims to in about the way you'd expect them, so if the description looks interesting, you'll probably enjoy it. The game has a fairly simple core mechanic: survive until x year. However, the facets that go into maximizing your chances for survival are many and are quite novel. I really enjoy pairing my strongest fighters and securing even stronger future generations.

The music in the game is lovely, and the voice acting is far better than I had anticipated (actually I hadn't anticipated ANY, but the voice acting is really very good). The visual style is a little... art over realism, as it were. But it serves the game well enough that I, as a huge fan of realistic graphics, found myself not caring at all that I wasn't looking at lush forests and TressFX hair. The controls might seem slightly limited at first, but I quickly found they did their job effectively.

All in all, this game is great fun and I encourage you to grab it if you're on the fence about it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

That's a very original and entertaining game, like if X-COM met Game of Thrones for a crossover.

People tend to focus on combat, but what's really great about Massive Chalice is the strategy of breeding heroes and trying to have a minimally acceptable team to defend your lands when the Cadence attacks. It can be challenging as you have to plan ahead to have a balance of classes and also take care of the special buildings that give bonus to hero development and research of new 'technologies'.

What should you do? Have your best hero available to do battle or marry him with a fertile hero of another family so his offspring have a better chance of being as good (or better!) than himself? Should you appoint your most experienced hero as the standard to be followed by young heroes and risk having only inexperienced youngsters to fight the next invasion? Will they be able to survive without more powerful items and armor? Who will research it?

Combat itself is not that original or satisfying at this point, mostly because of balance issues. There are some enemies, especially later in the game, able to single handedly criple or even destroy an average party. Also, there are only 3 classes available. This greatly limits the number of tactics you can use to overcome the battles, and can lead to some repetition during the 300 year timespan of the game.

Of course, this is an unfinished product, so we can hope for the combat to get a little better and the planning phase to get more polishment and shine even more.

That said, if you like original and challenging games, Massive Chalice's world is surely a good palce for you to play only one more turn.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

¯\_(ツ)_/¯

It's an inferior reskin of rage aneurysm in game form X-Com: Enemy Unknown/Within that someone accidentally dumped the Crusader Kings bloodline number crunching into. It's so much like X-Com that it even has the same UI and controls, the same panic level and pick between two battles features, the crap RNG and touchy map movement. All that said, X-Com is an awesome, addicting game, so, I mean, eh, this can't possibly be that bad. I'd wait until it goes live but if you like X-Com and want more of that, this gives you X-Com with a low-fi fantasy skin.

At the moment, the classes and mobs do not feel well balanced, with at least one seemingly useless class and a number of monsters that are just no fun to fight, but this will hopefully change before a full release. The gameplay stretches on for years in game but feels more breakneck than X-Com which is supposed to take place over a few months. I didn't find it very enjoyable: I was simultaneously bored by the lack of battles and overwhelmed trying to get a handle on mechanics, stats, traits and personalities before my soldiers died. Also had a lot of trouble actually keeping my ranks up; at one point I had 6 Hunters and that was it.

Also, this is just petty, but I really liked the idea of their art direction but it didn't seem well executed in game; it felt unfinished. When I started my first forest map battle, my first thought was, Wow
date: they slapped some really low res textures onto the tree meshes from X-Com didn't they?""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you took you standard turn-based strategy game like X-Com, added a little bit of the Sims and Pokemon breeding, and sprinkle on the sass and humor of Double Fine all over it, you get something close, yet at the same time nothing near what Massive Chalice is. A definite evolutionary experiment for the genre that can end up being revolutionary or a downright disaster. You might wanna take some notes, eugenics is involved.


Gameplay: 92/100 A-

Massive Chalice plays like any other turn based strategy game at first, moving your units into positions which offer a greater tactical advantage, setting up a trap, or pulling off a successful raid. While the combat mechanics are all familiar, moving, using skills, on and on, that is about as similar Massive Chalice is to other games of the like, specifically X-Com: Enemy Unknown, since it's one of the more recent successes of the genre. The rest of the gameplay isn't even on the battlefield, but in your kingdoms, putting units together in partnerships from the multitudes of clans, breeding them to produce offspring who will pass down traits to help improve your army as time goes by, some will die of old age, others in battle, some at random, some not so random - the list just goes on and on and you have to decide which way you want things to go, all the while fending off this nebulous invading force. Essentially, Massive Chalice takes away the random chance with the units and puts it in the players trusting hands, making everyone your responsibility. Good luck!


Audio: 90/100 A-

Being an Early Access game, things are bound to change, and the music isn't exempt from this. That said, the music that is currently in the game is well made and fits the atmosphere of the game and environments. This goes for the sound effects as well, since some sound like placeholders for better samples, others feel well polished and ready to go into your ears. The voice acting is done fairly well, too. The two main voices coming from the Massive Chalice itself, features a male being and a female being, both two different personalities that bicker and support you all at once or at each other. At times they are hilarious, while other times they can be a bit of a downer as you're trying to turn the tide of the war and one pipes up and says Their numbers are endless and instantly replaced
date:
we must grow into maturity..." or something like that.


Visuals: 95/100 A

reviewText:
I was prepared for the same disappointment with Massive Chalice as I was with Spacebase DF-9. Long story short, people paid money and the Double Fine gave up on making the game, leaving everyone with a game that essentially never left alpha. But funnily enough, that wasn’t the case. Massive Chalice is essentially XCOM cross the map from the Game of Thrones introduction.

The enemies are varied and you can use their corpses ro craft new weapons, items and armor. Someone dies and there’s no getting back up again. Every mission is very simple: Kill all the Cadence monsters. With no variance, the game can be a little repetitive at times. But I don’t enjoy this game for the combat.

Almost unheard of, but one of the best parts about this game is the micro-managing between battles. And here’s where the Game of Thrones comes into it. You have several families/clans under your control which you place into keeps around your kingdom. Each clan has a dominant class and by intermingling different clans, you can produce hybrid classes and place emphasis on certain traits. You are an immortal dictator with complete oversight of your kingdom, the oversight and totalitarian control needed to save the realm.

I have picked up some issues. The classes are really, really unintuitive. An alchemist has a giant claw and throws flasks, a hunter has a crossbow and a caber just bashes the ♥♥♥♥ out enemies with a caber (log of wood used in the Scottish sport Caber Tossing). The hybrid classes are even more confusing with names like Blastcapper, Enforcer and Boomstriker (lucky guess as to what hybrids they are).

Asides from this, still a good game. It has a simple eloquence to it which Double Fine have always had a knack for. Even though your heroes die of old age, the next generation start at a higher level, meaning that you feel like you’re progressing despite losing your best warriors to the ravages of time. Double-Fine have made some game design choices which are great. Knowing about the game before I started, I expected heaps of flaws. But somehow Double-Fine have managed to find ways around it.

For full review, visit: http://icarusreviews.net/2015/08/23/massive-chalice/

Time for playthrough: Took 13.7 hrs to finish game on normal (incl tutorial) without any saving/reloading. I assume if you play with mouse instead of gamepad it's down to 12 hours.

Game-play: You are mostly managing your heroes as resources and try to breed (!) better heroes - the bloodline system works and is fun, though it's not worth going into the details too much, as few heroes will have more than 2 fights in them before they die of old age and get replaced by younger ones. It's well designed though.

Once you got dozens of buildings up the game begins to get slow and sluggish as constantly someone dies of old age and you need to select replacements.

Battle: It's basically X-COM and I wasn't impressed.

Still recommend it as it was fun. Just make sure you grab it with a huge discount.
